title: How to Stop Throwing Up After Drinking Alcohol: Remedies & Prevention Tips

steps.title: Drink small sips of water to rehydrate.
steps.content: Drink small sips of water to rehydrate. Throwing up can make you dehydrated, which can interfere with your body’s circulation and lead to more serious complications. After throwing up, drink small sips of water every 15 minutes for the first 3-4 hours. You can even suck on ice chips if you’re feeling warm. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you’re struggling to keep fluids down, wait about 30 minutes to sip water after vomiting. You can also sip clear fluids and drinks with electrolytes, like broth, sugar-free ginger ale, sports drinks, or apple juice.

steps.title: Eat small amounts of bland foods.
steps.content: Eat small amounts of bland foods. Crackers, toast, plain oatmeal, and grits are good options because they require less digestion and, therefore, are less likely to irritate the lining of your stomach and intestines. [2] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Just remember to go slow and start off with small bites. You can also try eating foods like bananas, rice, and applesauce (part of the BRAT diet). For 24-48 hours after vomiting avoid foods that can upset your stomach or make nausea worse. This includes: fatty, greasy, sugary, or spicy foods, dairy products, alcohol, soda, and caffeinated beverages. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Take an over-the-counter pain reliever.
steps.content: Take an over-the-counter pain reliever. Taking medication with small bites of food can prevent a stomach ache. Stick to aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen or naproxen. Do not take acetaminophen (Tylenol) after drinking—it can be toxic to your liver when mixed with alcohol. [4] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Alternatively, take antacids to help settle your stomach.

steps.title: Avoid drinking more to “feel better.”
steps.content: Avoid drinking more to “feel better.” While “hair or the dog,” or drinking more alcohol to cure a hangover, may temporarily reduce your symptoms, there’s no scientific evidence that it works (and you’ll feel much worse when your blood alcohol levels return to zero). Give your stomach a break and do not drink again after throwing up.

steps.title: Get plenty of rest to ease hangover symptoms.
steps.content: Get plenty of rest to ease hangover symptoms. Sleeping is one of the best ways to help you feel better after a night of drinking and throwing up. Rest in an upright seated position with your head elevated about 12 inches (30 cm) above your feet to reduce nausea. [5] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can try sleeping upright in a recliner or watching TV in a seated position until you feel well enough to go to bed. Avoid lying down in a flat position to rest, especially if you have acid reflux. This may cause you to start throwing up again.

steps.title: Consume ginger to reduce nausea.
steps.content: Consume ginger to reduce nausea. Studies show that ginger can help reduce nausea and settle an upset stomach. [6] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source So, drink a cup of ginger tea, chew on a piece of raw ginger, or take a ginger shot if you’re feeling queasy. To make ginger tea , peel a fresh knob of ginger, cut it into thin slices, and put a few slices in a cup. Pour in boiling water and let it steep for 10 minutes. [7] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source

steps.title: Apply acupressure to relieve nausea.
steps.content: Apply acupressure to relieve nausea. While it isn’t scientifically proven, you may be able to stop nausea with acupressure . [8] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Find the Neiguan (P-6) pressure point on your inner arm. Position your hand so that your palm is facing upwards. Place your middle three fingers across the wrist starting where the wrist meets your hand. The outside of the finger closest to your body should mark this pressure point P-6. Now you can use your thumb to press this point, moving in a circular motion for a short period of time. [9] X Research source You might gain additional relief by repeating this process on your other wrist.

steps.title: Avoid excessive motion.
steps.content: Avoid excessive motion. Sometimes, moving around can make you feel worse if you’re nauseous. [10] X Research source Move to a quiet room if you’re at a social gathering, and sit down until you’re feeling better. You may get relief if you rest in a propped up position. Activity may worsen nausea and can even cause vomiting.

steps.title: Know your alcohol limit.
steps.content: Know your alcohol limit. Different people process alcohol at different rates, which means you could have the same number of drinks as a friend but feel greater effects from the alcohol than they do. Your alcohol tolerance is generally linked to your weight and gender, but it can also be affected by a variety of factors, including your hormones and differing levels of enzymes responsible for metabolizing alcohol. [11] X Research source Use the following chart as a general guide on how many drinks it takes to reach a BAC of 0.08 (the legal limit in most states): [12] X Research source Men 120 to 140 lbs: 1-2 drinks per hour 150 to 180+ lbs: 2-3 drinks per hour 190 to 220+ lbs: 3-4 drinks per hour Women 90 to 110 lbs: 1 drink per hour 120 to 170 lbs: 1-2 drinks per hour 180 to 200+ lbs: 2-3 drinks per hour Note: One drink is equal to one 12 oz of beer with 5% alcohol, 1.5 oz of 80-proof liquor, or a 5 oz glass of wine with 12% alcohol.

steps.title: Pace yourself and stop drinking when you’ve reached your limit.
steps.content: Pace yourself and stop drinking when you’ve reached your limit. This might be harder than it sounds, especially when friends are encouraging you to have another drink. However, doing so keeps your blood alcohol levels from reaching the point of intoxication, which can prevent vomiting and other hangover symptoms. [13] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source As a general rule, try to limit yourself to one drink per hour. If someone is pressuring you to drink more, you could say, “I’m going to be sick if I have another” or “I have a busy day tomorrow so I can’t drink too much.”

steps.title: Drink 8 to 12 ounces of water for every alcoholic drink.
steps.content: Drink 8 to 12 ounces of water for every alcoholic drink. Alternating each alcoholic beverage with a glass of water can prevent dehydration and slow your alcohol intake. [14] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source This can help you over drinking and throwing up later. If you get super drunk, switch entirely to water. Drink it steadily, but do not chug or drink water to excess, as this can upset your stomach. Reader Poll: We asked 223 wikiHow readers how they prefer to pace themselves while drinking, and 52% of them said drinking water in between alcoholic drinks. [Take Poll]

steps.title: Eat something before drinking alcohol.
steps.content: Eat something before drinking alcohol. Food helps slow the absorption of alcohol into your bloodstream, which can keep your blood alcohol concentration lower. A heavier meal can offset the effects of alcohol on your body, and may prevent vomiting and other hangover symptoms. [15] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The best options are foods that contain protein, fat, and carbohydrates. This includes: a burger and sweet potato fries, salmon with rice pilaf and veggies, an egg and cheese sandwich, a tofu bowl with rice and stir-fried veggies, paneer or chicken tikka, or a bean burrito with cheese and veggies. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Stick to one type of alcohol and avoid mixing drinks.
steps.content: Stick to one type of alcohol and avoid mixing drinks. This makes it easier for you to keep track of how much alcohol you’ve consumed (so you can avoid drinking too much). For example, if you start with a drink with lower alcohol content, then switch to a drink with a higher alcohol content, you might forget or underestimate how much you’ve consumed. [17] X Research source Whether it’s beer, liquor, or wine, choose one and stick to it!

steps.title: Avoid darker-colored alcoholic beverages.
steps.content: Avoid darker-colored alcoholic beverages. Studies show that lighter-colored drinks like vodka, gin, light beer, and white wine are less likely to cause hangovers. Darker-colored drinks like whiskey, bourbon, scotch, brandy, dark beers, and red wine have congeners, which can cause more severe symptoms.

steps.title: Get some fresh air and avoid strong odors.
steps.content: Get some fresh air and avoid strong odors. Cooling yourself off is a big part of feeling better, especially if you’re drinking at a large party or social gathering. Going outside can distract you if you’re feeling nauseous and calm down your central nervous system. Strong smells can trigger your gag reflex, so it’s best to step outside if you’re feeling overstimulated. [18] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source As an added bonus, if you do vomit, it won't be while you're surrounded by people. Plus, throwing up outside requires less involved clean up!

steps.title: Listen to your body.
steps.content: Listen to your body. If you heave or gag, the best strategy to prevent vomiting is to quit drinking for the night. Vomiting doesn’t reduce your blood alcohol level, and drinking more could lead to something more serious, like alcohol poisoning. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Your body can’t process any more alcohol.
steps.content: Your body can’t process any more alcohol. When you drink alcohol, your liver breaks it down into less harmful substances. However, when you drink too much, your liver can’t break down alcohol fast enough and a toxic substance called acetaldehyde builds up in your bloodstream. This can cause nausea and vomiting as your body tries to get rid of it. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Alcohol irritates your stomach lining.
steps.content: Alcohol irritates your stomach lining. Drinking alcohol increases stomach acid production, which can cause nausea, vomiting, or belly pain. [21] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The more alcohol you drink, the greater the risk of these symptoms.

steps.title: No, making yourself throw up can put greater strain on your esophagus.
steps.content: No, making yourself throw up can put greater strain on your esophagus. Throwing up doesn’t reduce your blood alcohol level because the alcohol has already entered your bloodstream. However, forcing yourself to throw up can make it more likely to tear your esophagus, which can lead to bleeding and other serious complications. These include: [22] X Research source Dehydration Tooth damage Metabolic issues Gastrointestinal bleeding Damage to the stomach or esophagus lining Aspiration of vomit into the lungs, which can lead to pneumonia

steps.title: Seek emergency care if you have any signs of alcohol poisoning.
steps.content: Seek emergency care if you have any signs of alcohol poisoning. Alcohol poisoning is a potentially life threatening situation that occurs when someone drinks alcohol quicker than their body can process it. It also impairs a person’s gag reflex so they can’t prevent choking on their own vomit. Symptoms of alcohol poisoning include: [23] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Confusion Skin that’s pale or blue Having a seizure or fit Loss of consciousness Vomiting more than once Slow or irregular breathing Cold and clammy extremities Slurring words or being unable to speak Being unable to coordinate movement, like standing, walking, or picking things up
